s.text: Pace (2001) has argued that alien biochemistry will turn out to be the same as biochemistry on Earth, because there is one best way to do things and that natural selection will ensure that life everywhere discovers that way.
(Metabolism is used here to include an organism's life functions, biomass increase, and reproduction.)
Cleland and Chyba (2002) have suggested that life might be like water, hard to define phenomenologically, but easy to define at the fundamental level.
It makes sense, then, that the search for liquid water is currently the first step in the search for life on other worlds.
It is also unlikely that the oxygen release in the Gas Exchange experiment had a biological explanation, because the reaction was so rapid and persisted after heating.
It is also unlikely that the oxygen release in the Gas Exchange experiment had a biological explanation, because the reaction was so rapid and persisted after heating.
Movement (either microscopic or macroscopic) in response to stimuli or in the presence of food can be a convincing indicator of a living thing.
It makes sense, then, that the search for liquid water is currently the first step in the search for life on other worlds.
The obvious diversity of life on Earth overlies a fundamental biochemical and genetic similarity.
Life on Mars is also likely to be the same at the top of the table: at the ecological level.

Pace (2001) has argued that alien biochemistry will turn out to be the same as biochemistry on Earth, because there is one best way to do things and that natural selection will ensure that life everywhere discovers that way.
While it may be similar at the top (ecological) and bottom (chemical) levels, life on Mars could be quite alien in the middle, in the realm of biochemistry.
Life on Mars is also likely to be the same at the top of the table: at the ecological level.
